sect1.title: Insufficient type arguments
sect1.para: Querydsl needs properly encoded List Set, Collection and Map properties in all code generation scenarios.
When using improperly encoded fields or getters you might the following stacktrace:
sect1.programlisting: java.lang.RuntimeException: Caught exception for field com.querydsl.jdoql.testdomain.Store#products at com.querydsl.apt.Processor$2.visitType(Processor.java:117) at com.mquerydsl.query.apt.Processor$2.visitType(Processor.java:80) at com.sun.tools.javac.code.Symbol$ClassSymbol.accept(Symbol.java:827) at com.mysequerydslery.apt.Processor.getClassModel(Processor.java:154) at coquerydslema.query.apt.Processor.process(Processor.java:191) ... Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Insufficient type arguments for List querydslom.mysema.query.apt.APTTypeModel.visitDeclared(APTTypeModel.java:112) querydslom.mysema.query.apt.APTTypeModel.visitDeclared(APTTypeModel.java:40) at com.sun.tools.javac.code.Type$ClassType.accept(Type.java:696querydslt com.mysema.query.apt.APTTypeModel.<init>(APTTypeModel.java:55querydslt com.mysema.query.apt.APTTypeModel.get(APTTypeModel.java:48) at coquerydslema.query.apt.Processor$2.visitType(Processor.java:114) ... 35 more
sect1.para: Examples of problematic field declarations and their corrections:
sect1.programlisting:
private Collection names; // WRONG
private Collection<String> names; // RIGHT
private Map employeesByName; // WRONG
private Map<String,Employee> employeesByName; // RIGHT

sect1.title: Multithreaded initialization of Querydsl Q-types
sect1.para: When Querydsl Q-types are initialized from multiple threads, deadlocks can occur, if the Q-types have circular dependencies.
An easy to use solution is to initialize the classes in a single thread before they are used in different threads.

sect1.title: JDK5 usage
sect1.para: When compiling your project with JDK 5, you might get the following compilation failure:
The class file version 50.0 is used by Java 6.0, and 49.0 is used by Java 5.0.
Querydsl is tested against JDK 6.0 only, as we use APT extensively, which is available only since JDK 6.0.
If you want to use it with JDK 5.0 you might want to try to compile Querydsl yourself.
